text: So the 18% is basically how many times you would of won more than Â£1k by betting on random runners. It's also an indication of how many times you _wouldn't_ of ended up with that profit. The lower the %, the better as that indicates skill vs luck. Ideally it should be < 5% and preferably < 1%. It's not uncommon for a good strategy to be 0% over a large sample of bets.

text: If not then I would be inclined to exclude the friendlies

text: Yeah that's a good question for me - nope I don't model individual player performance. I guess the real question is what should I expect to be similar between team A vs B in a friendly league when compared to team A vs B in a competitive league. I don't follow football enough (or much at all really) to know this nuance, but perhaps it might be more common domain-specific knowledge for more religious football followers.

elements.text: Yeah that's a good question for me - nope I don't model individual player performance. text: My inclination is the same - ignore them and not worry about the nuance rather than try and incorporate whatever usefulness those friendly observations might have

text: Yeah I think the information content of these results is low enough that it's close to the same as if you hadn't observed the match in the first place

elements.text: Yeah I think the information content of these results is low enough that it's close to the same as if you hadn't observed the match in the first place

text: Without any expertise at all - doesn't it depend on what your options are? If the friendlies are all you have then I imagine you use them but if you've got other data that's reasonably fresh then I would have thought you can afford to discard them?

elements.text: Without any expertise at all - doesn't it depend on what your options are? If the friendlies are all you have then I imagine you use them but if you've got other data that's reasonably fresh then I would have thought you can afford to discard them?

text: what % of the data set would be these friendlies? I suspect anything <5% wont have any real effect on training, whether its correct or not to include them.

elements.text: what % of the data set would be these friendlies? I suspect anything <5% wont have any real effect on training, whether its correct or not to include them.

text:
<@UBS7QANF3> yeah I think the liklehood of something useful being in the friendlies that isn't already covered by data from competitive leagues is quite low. So in the absence of any expert saying "no, wait, you can extract X which is very useful", I will just ignore friendlies :slightly_smiling_face:

<@UGV299K6H> indeed, I suppose my question should have been phrased "from common knowledge, would one be an idiot to exclude friendlies from assessing the strength/scoring ability/etc of a team, or would one not be missing out".

<@ULDAVFDRP> they are quite a huge chunk of a the games in the past few months, probably if you sorted a list of competitions by game count over the last month or two they'd have the highest game count. At the same time the last few months are the quietest periods for football so they are quite irrelevant for most of the year

text: Im always one for giving things a shot however it sounds quite dangerous to me, as your training set games from the previous two months vs the next two month are fundamentally different (hard to phrase). In horses it might be like using the tail end of the jumps season to predict the flat season

text: these Friendly games are dying out, they're roughly 2.5% of games currently and excluding them from the model also means excluding them from betting so it's as if they never happened (and the hypothesis is that the presence of them does not have some predictive ability on performance in competitive leagues). The top chart is total number of games per day across all competitions in my dataset, and the bottom is Friendlies only

text: Volumes are different across leagues, some games have 10s of millions put through, some games have less than a hundred quid. It's not particularly volatile (relative to horses) because a large part of the price simply reflects how much time is left in the game + some small skew (for inplay).

text: MC is as simple as comparing your actual P&L to what it would be if you had no strategy and simply bet on random runners.
